Like all drug companies, Merck pays influential doctors to promote its drugs.
One of the doctors Merck recruited to help launch its painkiller Vioxx was Gurkirpal Singh of Stanford University.
Merck wanted Singh because he had worked on a seminal study that had established the need for new painkillers such as Vioxx, and its rival, Celebrex, that were gentler on the stomach.
In 1999, the year Vioxx was launched, Singh gave 40 lectures in seven months for Merck.
The company paid him up to $2,500 apiece.
Then, in 2000, Merck got evidence that Vioxx could be bad for the heart.
Singh drew attention to those potential problems in his lectures to doctors.
Merck canceled many of his talks.
And when Singh still didn't back off, Merck senior vice president Dr. Louis Sherwood called Singh's boss at Stanford to complain.
Singh's boss, James Free, says he felt threatened by the call.
He says he was left with a sense that if he didn't rein in Singh, Merck's financial support for medical research at Stanford would be at risk.
Is it wrong for a drug company to make that phone call?
David Rothman is director of the Center on Medicine as a Profession at the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons.
The answer to that question is yes.
If research grants become a tool for marketing, we've crossed a line.
Ted Mayer, a lawyer representing Merck, says it's unfair to say that Sherwood's call implied any threat to Stanford's research funding.
Sherwood was a former academic himself.

I think what Dr. Sherwood was trying to do was to speak peer to peer, as somebody who had been a chief of medicine at respected hospitals, to a colleague, and to express his view of the science to his colleague in a context where he expected that he would get a fair hearing for his view.
Sherwood also denies he made threats to Stanford or anybody else.
Singh's boss wasn't the only senior academic whom Sherwood called.
He also called heads of departments at seven other institutions to complain about researchers there who had criticized Vioxx.
Drummond Rennie is deputy editor of the Journal of the American Medical Association.
They'd never pick up the phone did he not represent real money in the form of real grants coming in large amounts and that's the problem.
Everybody is in hawk, if you like, to money they already have and the expectation of future money from the big pharmaceutical companies.
Merck spread money liberally to cultivate doctors and researchers who could help Vioxx's sales.
The company offered a range of inducements from speaking fees to research grants, as well as meals in fancy restaurants and trips to resorts.
Vioxx racked up billions in sales.
But the arrangement proved risky for public health.
By one estimate, Vioxx caused at least 38,000 deaths from heart attacks.
Merck disputes that number.
David Rothman of Columbia says it's time to re-evaluate the relationship between drug companies and academic medical researchers.
Look, we all knew that drug reps were company salespeople and we all knew that docs were a little bit too friendly to get their big dinners and their trips, and we've begun to rein that in.
And we haven't really yet begun to figure out how to control relationships between academic medical institutions and drug companies.
Rothman says there's no question the drug companies and universities need each other.
We do want new drugs.
We do want new discoveries.
We do want universities being able to take what they've learned about molecules over to drug companies to enable them to produce them and distribute them.
We don't have the luxury of saying, `Never the twain shall meet.'
But he and others say the terms of the alliance between academia and big drug companies must be more transparent and better regulated.
Otherwise, the risk is too great, that an arrangement that's meant to nurture research and public health may poison it.
Snigdha Prakash, NPR News, Washington.
On Fridays, the business report focuses on your money and today we're going to ask how the headlines affect your finances.

Good morning.
Good morning, Steve.
It's great to be with you.
Based on the readers that you hear from, how often do people change their investment strategies based on the day's news?
Way too often.
You know, we all tend to react to the news way too much.
And one of the things that you learn from studying investor psychology is we all have this tendency to extrapolate what's going on right now.

So, you know, you go back to early 2000 and people looked at what was going on with technology stocks and how they're rising, and they extrapolated that rise into the future and that caused a lot of people to go up and load up on technology stocks.
You go to sort of late 2002 and early 2003 and people saw stocks going down and said, `Hey, you know, stocks are just always going to fall.
Of course, the next thing you know, you know, they were taking off.

And today, you know, you look around, and a lot of people are taking the strong returns in the real estate market and extrapolating those endlessly into the future and saying that real estate, you just can't go wrong with it.
And all these were mistakes in your view?
Well, it was certainly a mistake in early 2000 to load up on technology stocks.
It was certainly a mistake in late 2002 and early 2003 to avoid stocks.
And I suspect that a lot of people who were going out and buying huge houses thinking that this is the road to wealth, it may turn out to be a little disappointing.
Every once in a while you must hear about an investor who does something truly crazy or seems truly crazy to you based on the way the markets seem to be heading.
Edition of the political junkie.
One of the things that you read about right now, which I find absolutely astonishing, is you hear about people buying unbuilt condos with a view to sign them again six months later.
I mean, real estate is a long-term investment.
What if the market turns sour?
It's very costly to buy and sell real estate.
And most of the time people are putting down 20 percent of the purchase price and borrowing the other 80 percent.
It doesn't take much of a drop in prices to wipe all the money that you put down.
The problem is that our emotional time frame and our investing time frame are totally different.
People tend to look out no further than one year and that's one of the reasons why they get so caught up in short-term results.
When was the last time you changed your investment strategy?

With my portfolio what I do is I have written targets for how much I'm going to have in large stocks, how much I'm going to have in small stocks, how much I'm going to have in bonds, and then once a year, I sit down, I calculate where I stand and then I revamp my portfolio to get it back in line with those target percentages.
And what this does is two things: First, it keeps my portfolio's risk level under control.
For instance, after a year like 2004 where stocks did pretty well, I was selling stocks at the end of the year because I'd became overinvested in stocks.

But the other thing it does is it can boost your portfolio's long-run return and the reason is this: If you're continually rebalancing within your stock portfolio, say, you know, lightening up on foreign stocks when they do really well, adding to small stocks when they do poorly, you're essentially forced to buy low and sell high.
And as anybody who's ever invested in the stock market knows, that's a great way to make money.
And in effect you're pushing your investment away from where the news headlines would suggest you should be putting your investment.
As the personal finance columnist for The Wall Street Journal, if anybody knows where the market's headed or at least they think they know where it's headed, it should be me.

But, you know, I've been doing this long enough to know my guess is no better than anybody else's, and so instead of playing my hunches, it makes a lot more sense to have these target portfolio percentages and rebalance back to them.
That way, even when I'm thinking that hey, you know, stocks had a nice run, you know, maybe this is where I should have my money, I'm forced to go in the opposite direction.
People will sometimes talk about a buying opportunity.
They'll say well, the market went down or this particular sector of the market went down, this is the time to buy.
Would you advise just rejecting that and still just re-evaluating your portfolio once a year as you do or occasionally?
If we get a really big move in the market, if stocks suddenly drop 20 percent, you know, in the middle of the year I might sit down, I might run the numbers then and rebalance midyear.
The really important thing is that you just want to be disciplined about it.
Jonathan Clements is personal finance columnist for The Wall Street Journal.
